results.title: The Alcoholic: study of a disease
results.brief_description: Alcoholics suffer from one of the most destructive diseases in our society. Their problems and the possibility of their cure are considered in this film which introduces several people who are or have been alcoholics. An authority on the disease and its treatment, Dr. Alfred Byrne, distinguishes between the true alcoholic and the heavy drinker, and describes the course of compulsive drinking using the “pattern of progression” designed by the World Health Organization. Explains the physical effects of alcohol and the enormous amount of help offered by Alcoholics Anonymous to people who suffer from the disease.

results.title: Alcohol, tobacco and drugs versus physical fitness
results.creator_credit: George J. Holland and AIMS Instructional Media
results.brief_description: Stresses a positive approach to avoidance of drug abuse in young people by associating exercise and physical health with the ‘good life’. Young people are shown cycling, back-packing, skiing and surfing. The effects of stimulants and depressants on mental and physical performance are discussed.

results.title: Alcohol: the problem with drinking
results.creator_credit: Sherry James, Don Anderson, Alcohol and Drug Dependency Board of Tasmania and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: The problem of teenage/adolescent drinking. Discusses some of the reasons why they drink, their attitude towards alcohol, and some problems associated with drinking. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: Alcohol: the first decision
results.creator_credit: Don Dickerson and King Screen Productions
results.brief_description: Surveys what young people are confronted with when deciding whether or not to drink, including seeing their parents drink, seeing advertisements for liquor in newspapers, magazines, and on billboards, and hearing alcoholism made a subject for levity on radio and television.

results.title: The Alcohol problem: what do you think?
results.creator_credit: Michael Ahnemann, Milan Herzog, Stanley Croner and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: A film in three parts: Part 1 looks at the social, historical and economic aspects of alcohol; Part 2 analyses the chemistry of alcohol and the physiological effects of drinking and Part 3 shows experiments with mice revealing the physical dependency and withdrawal symptoms caused by alcoholism. Also visits a hospital and talks to youthful alcoholics. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: Alcohol in the human body
results.creator_credit: Felix Forsman and Fennada Filmi Junior
results.brief_description: A cartoon showing the impact of alcohol on the nervous system. It portrays sensibly, objectively and lucidly all effects of alcohol in the human body, and the problems these pose in our society. It leaves the viewer to draw his own conclusions.

results.title: Alcohol: how much is too much
results.creator_credit: Alan Capps, Frank Gardonyi, Ingvar Grimsgaard, Lou Lilly, Quartet Films and West
results.brief_description: An open-minded film which discusses social and physiological effects of alcohol. It is particularly designed for elementary grades. The film considers alcohol through such facts as its abuse as a drug, and its physiological effects on the brain and other parts of the human body. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Alcohol: a new focus
results.creator_credit: Noel Nosseck, American Educational Films and Directions Unlimited
results.brief_description: Points out that everyone, at some time in his life, has to decide whether or not to drink, how much to drink and under what circumstances. Looks at the historical facts of the temperance debate, drinking traditions and effects of alcohol on the body. Builds up a case against unwise drinking habits. Narrated by James Brolin.

results.title: Albury: year round holiday centre
results.brief_description: A look at Albury, holiday and convention city, and its surrounding resorts. Shows the numerous amenities they can offer to the tourist or visitor. Points of interest seen are Lake Hume, Beechworth and its historic buildings and Mount Beauty and skiing at Falls Creek. No further credits available.
